questiontext.text: A person or group as a recipient of nursing care who is being care in a hospital or clinic is referred to as:

answer.text: Consumer
Costumer
Patient
Client
Target group

questiontext.text: A nurse provides an explanation to the patient and provides an opportunity for the patient and family to make decisions regarding the patient's surgical plan. Nurses have applied principles and values in caring for patients. What are the criteria for the nurse as a professional that the nurse has shown?

answer.text: Have a body of knowledge
Applying the code of ethics
Discipline in taking Action
Active in carrying out organizational activities
Provide special care to patients

questiontext.text: In the history of nursing, the following are the nurses who are known to be the first to introduce a nursing philosophy based on environmental hygiene and nutrition…

answer.text: Clara Barton
Dorothea Dix
Linda Richard
Florence Nightingale
Isabel Hampton Robb

questiontext.text: In the history of world nursing, the first nurse to attend training and graduate from nursing school and introduce the use of uniforms for nurses was

answer.text: Clara Barton
Dorothea Dix
Linda Richard
Florence Nightingale
Isabel Hampton Robb

questiontext.text: In the history of world nursing, when was the nursing process introduced and the International Council of Nurses (ICN) formed?

answer.text: Before World War II
During World War II
After World War II
Beginning of AD
Early 1900

questiontext.text: A nurse taking care a patient with advanced cervical cancer. The patient just wants to go home and wants to be face her end of life at home. The nurse explains to the family and recommends discussing the patient's wishes. What is the professional role shown by the nurse?

answer.text: Care provider
Communicator
Educator
Advocate
Manager

questiontext.text: A nurse discusses with a patient and family the procedure for changing a wound dressing while at home. The patient's family demonstrates how to change the wound dressing. What is the professional role shown by the nurse?

answer.text: Care provider
Communicator
Educator
Advocate
Manager

questiontext.text: Various nursing theories that underlie the provision of nursing care and the development of the nursing profession are the criteria for nurses as a profession, namely:

answer.text: Extended education
Body of knowledge
Autonomy of decision
Code of ethics
Professional organization and publication

questiontext.text: A nurse in the operating room conveys to nursing students who practice in the room not to touch the patient except when giving a nursing intervention or performing an assessment. What is the concept of caring conveyed by the nurse?

answer.text: Nurses are not allowed to touch patients
Touch is a type of non-verbal communication
Touch is only used if the patient experiences pain
Touch is a form of relationship between nurse and patient
Touch can cause miscommunication with the patient

questiontext.text: One of the five caring processes described by Swanson is “knowing the patient”. Which of the following describes this process?

answer.text: Anticipate patient culture
Be physically and emotionally present with the patient
Demonstrate professional skills in providing nursing actions
Build an understanding of the patient's condition
Provide support to patients during the treatment process

questiontext.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the Emergency Department complaining of inability to urinate. Nurses in the ER provide catheter insertion measures to these patients in accordance with standard operating procedures (SOPs). Is the caring principle applied in accordance with Roach's theory in this case?

answer.text: Love
Competent
Self-confident
Commitment
According to conscience

questiontext.text: Which of the following describes the “doing for” caring process according to Swanson's caring theory?

answer.text: Conduct an in-depth study
Share the feelings experienced by the patient
Demonstrate skills in caring for patients
Provide alternative treatment
Provide an explanation of the actual condition of the patient

questiontext.text: A nurse visit to the patient's room, the patient tells the nurse that he wants to get well and goes home soon. What are the principles of caring applied by nurses?

answer.text: Present in front of the patient
Listen
Giving touch
Giving an explanation
Giving spiritual caring

questiontext.text: The concept which is a process of providing care and comfort for the patient is?

answer.text: Cure
Care
Core
Touch
Listening

questiontext.text: Which of the following is a strategy to create a work environment that supports nurses to implement caring behavior in the ward?

answer.text: Reduce the number of hours worked
Reduce the number of nurses per shift
Increase the number of nurses each shift
Support nurses to document nursing care
Support nurses to discuss nursing care that has been implemented

questiontext.text: The caring behavior shown by the nurse towards the patient's family is:

answer.text: Families play an active role in patient care
Forbidding the family to help care because it is the nurse's job
Make patient care decisions
Advise the family to continue to accompany the patient
Encourage families to always listen to patient complaints

questiontext.text: A patient is planned for surgery because of a cancer diagnosis. The patient said he was afraid and anxious about undergoing the surgery process. The nurse suggested to pray to God for the surgery to go smoothly and leave everything to God. What is the caring behavior applied by the nurse?

answer.text: Touch
Listening
Knowing the patient
spiritual care
Providing presence

questiontext.text: Aspects related to the ability to perform movements that involve certain body parts and are carried out by small muscles such as observing something, pinching, writing, reading are aspects of...

answer.text: Independence
Socialize
Rough motoric skill
Fine motoric skill
Speech and Language Skills

questiontext.text: The stage of growth and development with characteristics of curiosity, starting to recognize gender differences and tending to imitate the behavior of adults around them is the age stage.

answer.text: 3-4 years
4-6 years
7-9 years old
10-13 years old
14-18 years old

questiontext.text: One of the developmental disorders of children with slower development than normal children and factors such as congenital heart defects, motor hypotonia is a disease

answer.text: Stunting
Dyslexia
Cerebral palsy
Down syndrome
Mental retardation

questiontext.text: What is the principle of caring that involves parents in the implementation of nursing actions?

answer.text: Atraumatic care
Disease prevention
Family centered care
Play during hospitalization
Child-oriented environment

questiontext.text: Which of the following the intervention in atraumatic care?

answer.text: Provide children's age-appropriate play equipment
Encouraging parents to be involved in care
Provide a playroom for his friends
Encourage children to bring their favorite toys
Provide space for parents to live in the same room with their children

questiontext.text: The role of nurses in providing guidance to patients is called?

answer.text: Educator
Counselor
Coordinator
Collaborator
Change agent

questiontext.text: The nurse's function in its implementation is independent based on nursing science (responsible for the consequences arising from the actions taken). What is the kind of nurse role?

answer.text: Education
Counselor
Dependent
Independent
Interdependent

questiontext.text: Nurses play a role in meeting basic human needs through the provision of nursing services using the nursing process, from simple to complex. Which of the following nurse role that implemented?

answer.text: Educator
Care giver
Counselor
Consultant
Coordinator

questiontext.text: Which the following nurse role called that A nurse providing services or other information, especially in taking consent for nursing actions given to patients, maintaining and protecting patient rights.

answer.text: Care giver
Consultant
Coordinator
Change agent
Client advocate

questiontext.text: The inhibiting factors in carrying out the nurse's advocacy role include, except…

answer.text: Weak code of ethics
Family emotional state
The number of nurses is minimal
Knowledge of the patient's condition
Lack of attention to organization

questiontext.text: Guiding children in the golden age through games of arranging blocks, buying, selling and houses. What is the purpose of the game on the case?

answer.text: stimulate sensory
Learn to role play
Teaching negotiation
Teach counting
Educate good habits

questiontext.text: What is the internal factor that influence growth and development?

answer.text: Score
Nutrition
Temperament
Pattern of interaction
Health status

questiontext.text: Parents provide opportunities for children to walk alone visit neighbors to play and socialize with other children How old is the child in the caring application in this case?

answer.text: 2-3 years
3-4 years
4-5 years
6-7 years
7-8 years

questiontext.text: A 17-year-old teenager since menstruation has experienced an increase in weight, she likes to try new things such as make-up styles and clothes, has many friends when he makes long calls, but she is easily stressed if his wishes are not in accordance with the wishes of his friends. What is the caring application in this case?

answer.text: Recommend diet to avoid obesity
Help to stay focused on his education
Suggest to be able to choose the right friend
Help to adjust the appearance of his age
Help develop conflict resolution strategies

questiontext.text: A father retired 1 month ago, his 2 children left the house because they are married, his wife is 2 years older and does not work, now they have more time together. What is the caring application on the case?

answer.text: Assist in self-care
Help deal with loss
Maintain independent ability
Accept the chosen new lifestyle
Help make a life change plan

questiontext.text: The judgment of the decision maker, whether or not an action is right, this is definition of?

answer.text: Value
Ethics
Principle
Standard

questiontext.text: Nurses work to respect values, culture and religious survival. The statement of the code of ethics regulates the relationship between nurses and…

answer.text: Client
Profession
Practice
Public
Peers

questiontext.text: Improving health, preventing disease, maintaining health and reducing suffering is the responsibility of nurses. What is the nurse's belief in implementing these responsibilities?

answer.text: Humans with their uniqueness
Nursing practice respects human dignity and rights
Nursing services with individual, family and community targets
The need for nursing services in different places is not the same
Nurses can hold on to personal secrets

questiontext.text: A patient is admitted to the hospital with a head injury due to a traffic accident, the nurse informs the doctor about the patient's condition to get follow-up treatment. What function does the nurse perform in this case?

answer.text: Independent
Dependent
Interdependent
Autonomy
Coordinator

questiontext.text: Nursing is a profession. Which the following of the characteristics of the profession?

answer.text: A graduate from higher education
Have a code of ethics as a practice guide
Doing service for human welfare
Learned through a professional education process
Demonstrate independent appearance, activity and function

questiontext.text: A condition when various health professions work together with patients, patients' families, the community and other health professions to provide the highest quality health services is definition of?

answer.text: Interprofessional education
Intraprofessional education
Patient safety
Intraprofessional collaboration
Interprofessional collaboration

questiontext.text: The following are core competencies of the health profession, except.....

answer.text: Provide patient-centered care
Work as part of an interdisciplinary team - work together, collaborate, communicate and integrate care within the team to ensure that care is sustainable and reliable
Show broad insight
Practicing evidence-based medicine
Focus on quality improvement

questiontext.text: During the clinical practice process, internship physician and nurse student were assigned to manage one patient in the treatment room. In the morning, internship physician took anamnesis and interviewed patients regarding their health conditions. Furthermore, the nurse student conducted an assessment by asking the same thing, the patient was reluctant to answer the question because he felt that the question had been submitted and had been answered so that the patient felt disturbed. Based on this case, in order to improve health services to patients, what skills should the two students develop?

answer.text: Ability to deal with patients
Skills in conducting interviews with patients
Ability to build trusting relationships
Ability to appreciate between professions
Inter-professional communication and team work

questiontext.text: Some of the benefits of practicing interprofessional collaboration in health services are as follows, except.....

answer.text: Improve communication
Improving the quality of health services
No problems will arise
Strengthen professional identity
​​​​​​​Patient safety and optimal patient outcomes

questiontext.text: Ms. A is a new nurse who complained to the work condition in her department. Ms. A thinks that senior nurses are too proud of other professions and do not dare to express their opinions regarding nursing care to other professions. Miss A think that interprofessional collaboration at the hospital did not go well and one of the factors that cause it is the absence of interprofessional education (IPE) obtained when a senior nurse education. Here are the advantages IPE carried out ..... 1) Increase hospital admissions, 2) Improve patient safety, 3) Reduce education costs, 4) Improve workplace practices and productivity

answer.text: 1, 2 & 3 are correct
1 & 3 are correct
2 & 4 are correct
only 4 is correct
All is correct

questiontext.text: In the development of interprofessional teams to improve patient health services, there are several challenges that can hinder the optimal performance of a team, namely....

answer.text: Time-consuming communication between team members
Patient commitment
Reducing use of health services
Customizable team member schedule
​​​​​​​Abundant resources

questiontext.text: Functioning as a filter for various experiences related to human relations or the relationship between nurses and their clients in everyday life is a function of...

answer.text: Moral
Value
Norm
Ethics
Ethical

questiontext.text: Rules that can be used as a reference for someone's behavior related to good and bad actions that someone does and are the definition of ….

answer.text: Moral
Ethics
Value
Norm
Ethical

questiontext.text: An elderly patient aged 60 years was hospitalized in the digestive room with complaints of decreased consciousness, fell out of bed. The results of the study found that the patient's bed protector was not installed. What is the value of the nurse related to this case?

answer.text: Truth
Aesthetics
Equality
Human dignity
​​​​​​​Justice

questiontext.text: The essence of values in professional nursing practice which means putting others first is….

answer.text: Aesthetics
Equality
Altruism
Freedom

questiontext.text: Mr. A 69-year-old lives in a nursing home. The results of the assessment: the client experienced weakness in both lower extremities. The client asked the nurse for help him to the bathroom but the nurse refused because nurse should prepared feeding another patient. The nurse does not want to help the client because the client smells and is dirty. What value did the nurse violate?

answer.text: Aesthetics
Altruism
Truth
Autonomy

questiontext.text: A boy, 5 years old with a diagnosis of Labioplatoschizis . Two nurses want to change the dressing on the patient. While the nurse changed the dressing, another nurse took a picture/photo of the process and uploaded the photo for status updates on Instagram. What are the ethical principles associated with the case?

answer.text: Non-Maleficience
Confidentiality
Beneficence
Veracity
Justice

questiontext.text: Mrs. A 35 year old, postpartum 12 hours ago. After 4 hours of birth, the patient's baby died. Currently the nurse is communicating with the family about efforts to convey the baby's condition to the patient. What ethical principles are being followed by nurses?

answer.text: Beneficence
Fidelity
Veracity
Non Maleficence
Confidentiality

questiontext.text: What is the following Ethical issues that often arise in maternity nursing?

answer.text: Handling HIV/AIDS patients
Abortion
Euthanasia
Patient abuse/abandonment

questiontext.text: Ms. A is a nurse, she will move a patient from a bed to a wheelchair, when she is going to sit a patient into a wheelchair the patient falls because the chair moves backwards due to the wheelchair's wheels being unlocked. What action did the nurse take in this case?

answer.text: Careless
Malpractice
Negligence
Not careful
Incautious

questiontext.text: A nurse receives a salary at the end of the month after an assessment of her performance as a nurse is carried out. What did the nurse receive in this case?

answer.text: Nurse's rights
Nurse's role
Nurse function
Nurse responsibilities

questiontext.text: Kozier et al (2004) explain the framework for solving ethical dilemmas, namely developing basic data and then identifying conflicts. What is the next step?

answer.text: Make decision
Determine the decision maker
Define the nurse's responsibilities
Making alternative actions and their consequences

questiontext.text: A patient's family asked the nurse to remove the Intravenous line, catheter and oxygen tube attached to his family who was in a coma due to a traffic accident, on the grounds that the patient would be brought home because he had been hospitalized for too long. What is the nurse's first action?

answer.text: Asking the family to be patient
Submit to the doctor in charge
Asking the family to sign the forced return statement
Explain the need for care and treatment of patients in the hospital
Preparing the patient to go home after removing the infusion, catheter and oxygen tube

questiontext.text: A nurse assists in an illegal abortion, the nurse has committed an act that is not in accordance with the science and tips of nursing in nursing services. What ethical principles did the nurse violate in this case?

answer.text: Justice
Fidelity
Autonomy
Beneficence
Non-Maleficence

questiontext.text: The nurse previously assessed the physical and mental readiness of a teenager before submitting the results of his examination, which turned out to be HIV positive. What ethical principles did the nurse apply to this case?

answer.text: Justice
Fidelity
Veracity
Autonomy
Beneficence

questiontext.text: Which of the following example of primary healthcare services?

answer.text: Immunization
Prenatal and well-baby care
Cancer screenings
Sport medicine
Home care

questiontext.text: What types of health services are included in the intensive care room at the hospital?

answer.text: Primary care
Preventive care
Secondary acute care
Tertiary care
Restorative care

questiontext.text: what is the type of nursing care method in which one nurse is responsible for the care of a particular patient for 24 hours a day , 7 days a week?

answer.text: case method
Functional method
Team nursing
Primary nursing
